intro: Hymenoxys haenkeana, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy yellow-orange composite flowers. The plant typically grows as an herbaceous perennial, reaching heights of up to 1 meter, with lance-shaped leaves that are hairy and grayish-green in color. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for gardens and landscapes. The flowers bloom from summer to fall, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
